raw_text:
Download chart debut is delayed
 
 The inclusion of downloaded music in the official singles chart has been delayed for a month.
 
 The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) had planned to include download formats in the chart from 20 March. But the date has been put back to 17 April to create a "level playing field" for independent labels. The BPI is concerned that independent repertoire is not adequately represented online and said they were looking at ways of rectifying it.
 
 BPI chairman Peter Jamieson said: "The inclusion of download formats in the Official UK Singles Chart is the most significant development in the charts for 20 years.
 
 "But for a multitude of reasons the current chart representation of independent repertoire at the major download outlets is poor. "I am very pleased we have secured this delay on behalf of independents. We have to try and establish a realistic 'level playing field' of opportunity. The Official UK Charts are run by The Official UK Charts Company (OCC) - a joint venture between the BPI and the British Association of Record Dealers (BARD). At an OCC board meeting on Wednesday, the OCC board agreed with BPI members that the 20 March start date be postponed. Download formats will now be included in the Official UK Singles Chart for the first time in the chart published on 17 April - the sales week beginning 10 April. The US has already merged downloaded singles into its Billboard Hot 100 chart.
llama3.2:1b: The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) has delayed the inclusion of download formats in the Official UK Singles Chart, originally scheduled for March 20.
This decision was made to create a "level playing field" for independent labels and rectify concerns that their repertoire is not adequately represented online.
The BPI's chairman said he was pleased with the delay and the OCC board agreed to postpone the start date of the chart.
llama3.2:3b: The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) has delayed the inclusion of downloaded music in the official UK singles chart from March 20 to April 17, citing concerns over independent labels' representation online and a need for a "level playing field".
gemma2:2b: The inclusion of downloaded music in the official UK Singles Chart has been delayed from March 20th to April 17th to ensure a "level playing field" for independent labels.
The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) wants to address poor representation of independent repertoire online before including downloads in the chart.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Downloaded music won't go into official charts until 17 April, according to British Phonographic Industry president Peter Jamieson.
The chart will be delayed by a month for independent labels who want to include their download formats in the Official UK Singles Chart and Singles Album Sales (OCSAS).
qwen2.5:1.5b: The inclusion of downloaded music in the official UK singles chart is delayed from March to April, due to concerns about independent label representation online and a desire for more realistic competition among all labels on the charts.
qwen2.5:3b: The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) initially planned to include download formats in the Official UK Singles Chart starting from March 20, but this date was postponed until April 17 to ensure an equitable representation of independent labels.
BPI chairman Peter Jamieson highlighted this change as significant for the industry's history.
The delay aims to level the playing field for independent repertoire, which is underrepresented on major download platforms.
This decision was approved by the OCC board during a meeting on March 3rd.

The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) had planned to include download formats in the chart from 20 March, but the date has been put back to 17 April to create a "level playing field" for independent labels.
BPI is concerned that independent repertoire is not adequately represented online and said they were looking at ways of rectifying it.
The OCC board meeting agreed with BPI members that the start date on Wednesday, the 20 March start date be postponed.
Download formats will now be included in the Official UK Singles Chart for the first time on 17 April - the sales week beginning 10 April.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and to the point, preserving key ideas and details while omitting unnecessary information.

It provides a clear overview of the main points in the original text:

1.
Download music has been delayed for a month.
The inclusion of downloaded music in the official singles chart has been delayed for a month.
The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) had planned to include download formats in the chart from 20 March.
But the date has been put back to 17 April to create a "level playing field" for independent labels.
Independent labels are concerned about their online presence and want to rectify it.
The inclusion of downloaded music in the official singles chart is the most significant development in the charts for 20 years.
But for a multitude of reasons, the current chart representation of independent repertoire at major download outlets is poor.
For a level playing field of opportunity, the OCC board agreed with BPI members to delay the start date of downloaded singles on 17 April.
Download formats will now be included in the Official UK Singles Chart for the first time in the chart published on 10 April.
The US has already merged downloaded singles into its Billboard Hot 100 chart.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The Official UK Singles Chart (OSLS) includes downloaded music scheduled for release on 20 March.
However, due to concerns about independent labels' representation, BPI delayed the start date to April 17th.
The chart is managed by The Official Charts Company (OCC), a joint venture between BPI and the British Association of Record Dealers (BARD).
tinyllama:1.1b: The inclusion of downloaded music in the official singles chart has been delayed for a month, according to the British Phonographic Industry (BPI).
The delay is meant to create a "level playing field" for independent labels, and BPI chairman Peter Jamieson praised this as the most significant development in the charts for 20 years.
However, independent retailers are concerned about how they will be represented online, and an OCC board meeting decided to postpone the launch date of the chart by one week.
The Official UK Charts are run jointly by the BPI and BARD, with a start date in 20 March being deferred to April 17.
tinydolphin:1.1b: BPI plans to include download formats in the official singles chart for a month.
phi:2.7b: Summary: BPI delayed including downloaded music in the official singles chart to create a level playing field for independent labels, as their repertoire is underrepresented at major download outlets.
Download formats will now be included in the chart starting from 17 April.
The US has merged downloaded singles into its Billboard Hot 100 chart.

The delay was agreed upon by the OCC board at a meeting on Wednesday, with download formats now included in the Official UK Singles Chart from the sales week beginning 10 April.
The US has already merged downloaded singles into its Billboard Hot 100 chart.
hermes3:3b: Download charts delayed by a month, to create level playing field for independent labels.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) delayed the inclusion of downloaded music in the official singles chart to 17 April, instead of 20 March, to create a level playing field for independent labels.

BPI chairman Peter Jamieson mentioned that the most significant development in the charts for 20 years is now being postponed due to poor representation of independent repertoire at major download outlets.

The Official UK Charts Company (OCC), a joint venture between the BPI and British Association of Record Dealers (BARD), will include downloaded formats starting with the 17 April chart, published during the sales week beginning 10 April.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The inclusion of downloaded music in the UK singles chart has been delayed from 20 March to 17 April to ensure fair representation for independent labels.
The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) expressed concerns that independent music is underrepresented online and sought ways to address this.
BPI chairman Peter Jamieson emphasized the significance of this change but stressed the need for a "level playing field."
The Official UK Charts Company (OCC) agreed to the delay at a board meeting.
Download formats will now be included in the chart published on 17 April, following the US, which has already integrated downloads into its Billboard Hot 100.
stablelm2:1.6b: The inclusion of downloaded music in the Official UK Singles Chart was delayed by one month to create a "level playing field" for independent labels, as the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) aims to represent independent repertoire better online.
The start date for this development has been postponed from March to April, with download formats included in the chart during the sales week starting on April 1st.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The inclusion of digital music downloads in the UK's Official UK Singles Chart has been postponed from 20 March to 17 April.
This delay, advocated by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI), aims to improve representation for independent labels, which currently face poor visibility at major download platforms.
BPI chairman Peter Jamieson emphasized this change's significance as a major development in the charts for over two decades.

The decision was made during an OCC board meeting on Wednesday, with the board supporting BPI members' request to delay the implementation to establish a fairer "level playing field" for independent artists.
